tweets.text:
Framework is ‚Äúpausing‚Äù sales of some laptop models in the USA‚Ä¶ because of ‚Äútariffs‚Äù.

This is truly peculiar, and doesn‚Äôt pass the sniff test.

1) The price can be adjusted on the imported product to compensate for the tariff.  That‚Äôs how it works and the math is incredibly simple.

2) The USA is not the only country that imposes import tariffs on Taiwan.  In fact‚Ä¶ *most* countries have tariffs with Taiwan.  (I‚Äôve included a *very* partial list as a screenshot.)

3) In fact, Framework already has been dealing with tariffs (many far more complex than the Taiwan to US import tariffs) for quite some time.  Which means this is nothing new for them.

4) Framework is not ceasing *all* sales in the US.  Just specific models.  Which makes this look more like an excuse for some other reason.

This smells like a political stunt.

Framework is a US company (San Francisco).  But they do their manufacturing in Taiwan.  If they built their computers in the USA, they would avoid import tariffs into the USA.  But they don‚Äôt and won‚Äôt.  Because Taiwan is cheap to build this stuff in.

Worth noting that I‚Äôve worked for multiple computer hardware companies (including at the executive level) where we had to deal with import tariffs (going multiple different directions).  I can speak on the subject of ‚Äúbuilding computers in one company and selling in another‚Äù with a reasonable level of authority.

Nearly every nation has tariffs with nearly every other nation.  Every one is different and many are in a constant state of flux.  Yes, tariffs can be annoying to calculate and properly document.  But it‚Äôs nothing a good spreadsheet can‚Äôt solve.

In short: This doesn‚Äôt smell right.  Is it a political stunt?  Or cover for a different motivation?

tweets.text:
History of Trade Tariffs: 

USA üá∫üá∏ vs. China üá®üá≥

A quick rundown of tariff changes between these economic giants:

‚Ä¢Pre-2001:
‚ó¶üá∫üá∏ USA: Applied MFN tariffs (avg. 3-4%) on Chinese goods under GATT.
‚ó¶üá®üá≥ China: Imposed tariffs averaging 15-20% on U.S. goods.
‚Ä¢2001 (China Joins WTO):
‚ó¶üá∫üá∏ USA: Reduced tariffs to avg. 2.7% on Chinese goods.
‚ó¶üá®üá≥ China: Lowered tariffs to avg. 8-10% on U.S. goods over time.
‚Ä¢2018 (Trump Trade War Begins):
‚ó¶üá∫üá∏ USA: Imposed 25% tariffs on $34B of Chinese goods (July 6), then $16B (Aug 23).
‚ó¶üá®üá≥ China: Matched with 25% tariffs on $34B (July 6), then $16B (Aug 23) of U.S. goods.
‚Ä¢2019:
‚ó¶üá∫üá∏ USA: Raised tariffs to 25% on $200B of Chinese goods (May), avg. reached 20%.
‚ó¶üá®üá≥ China: Imposed tariffs up to 25% on $110B of U.S. goods, avg. hit 21%.
‚Ä¢2020 (Phase One Deal):
‚ó¶üá∫üá∏ USA: Reduced tariffs on $120B from 15% to 7.5%, kept 25% on $250B.
‚ó¶üá®üá≥ China: Kept avg. tariffs at 21% on U.S. goods, offered exemptions.
‚Ä¢2021-2024 (Biden Era):
‚ó¶üá∫üá∏ USA: Maintained Trump-era tariffs; avg. 19-20% on Chinese goods.
‚ó¶üá®üá≥ China: Held avg. tariffs at 20-21% on U.S. goods.
‚Ä¢2025 (Liberation Day):
‚ó¶üá∫üá∏ USA: Imposed 10% tariff on all Chinese goods (April 5), avg. now 42.1%.
‚ó¶üá®üá≥ China: Added 10-15% tariffs on U.S. goods (April 10), avg. reached 34%.

üìä Takeaway: Tariffs escalated from low levels (2-10%) to a high-stakes battle, with the U.S. at 42.1% and China at 34% by 2025.

tweets.text:
If you are referring to the over quota tariffs, you have them too

The USA has over quota tariffs on Canada & other countries which was first initiated under Smoot Hawley Tariff Act in the 1930‚Äôs. 

The United States applies over-quota tariffs, also known as tariff-rate quotas (TRQs), to certain imported goods when they exceed a predetermined quota allowed at a lower or zero tariff rate. These tariffs protect domestic producers by making excess imports cost-prohibitive. 

### Dairy Products
The U.S. imposes significant over-quota tariffs on dairy to shield its producers. 
- **Cheese**: Rates vary by type:
  - Cheddar: 12% to 16.8% over-quota, but some specialty cheeses (e.g., Swiss) can hit $1.70/kg or higher specific duties, effectively 20-30% depending on price.
  - Blue-veined (e.g., Roquefort): Up to 35% or $2.11/kg.
  - Other cheeses: Often 10-25%, with specific duties (e.g., $1.05-$2.27/kg) adding cost.
- **Butter**: 10% to 30.9%, or specific rates like $1.541/kg, which can exceed 50% ad valorem equivalent for low-cost imports.
- **Milk Powder (Nonfat Dry Milk)**: Around 3.9% to 25%, with specific duties (e.g., $0.775/kg) boosting effective rates.
- **Fluid Milk/Cream**: Up to 77.2% or $0.657/liter, though rarely triggered due to low import volumes.

Quotas are small‚Äîe.g., 5.4 million kg for cheddar annually‚Äîand over-quota rates apply once exceeded. For context, U.S. dairy imports were $4.1 billion in 2023, mostly within-quota from partners like the EU and New Zealand.

### Sugar
Sugar TRQs are a cornerstone of U.S. agricultural policy:
- **Raw Cane Sugar**: Over-quota tariff is about 33.87 cents/kg (roughly 150-200% ad valorem, depending on world prices), compared to 1.4606 cents/kg within-quota.
- **Refined Sugar**: Up to 35.74 cents/kg over-quota (over 100% equivalent), vs. 3.6606 cents/kg within-quota.

The USDA sets quotas annually (e.g., 1.117 million metric tons for raw sugar in 2023), with over-quota rates deterring excess imports. Mexico, under USMCA, has quota-free access up to a negotiated limit, but beyond that, these rates apply.

### Beef
Beef TRQs target imports from non-FTA partners (e.g., outside USMCA, Australia, etc.):
- **Fresh/Chilled/Frozen Beef**: 26.4% over-quota, vs. 4-10% within-quota or free from FTA countries like Canada.
- Quota: Around 696,000 metric tons annually, with countries like Argentina facing over-quota rates if they exceed allocations.

### Peanuts
Peanuts have some of the highest U.S. over-quota tariffs:
- **Shelled Peanuts**: 131.8% over-quota, vs. 6.6 cents/kg within-quota.
- **Peanut Butter**: Up to 163.8% over-quota.
- Quota: About 20,000 metric tons, protecting U.S. growers in states like Georgia.

### Cotton and Tobacco
- **Cotton**: Over-quota rates can reach 31.4 cents/kg (roughly 36% equivalent), vs. 1.5 cents/kg within-quota. Quota is around 41,000 metric tons.
- **Tobacco**: Up to 350% over-quota (e.g., $4.62/kg), vs. 37.5 cents/kg within-quota, though imports are niche.

### Other Goods
- **Chocolate/Cocoa Products**: 15-20% over-quota, with specific duties (e.g., $0.52/kg).
- **Tuna (Canned)**: 12.5% over-quota, vs. 6% within-quota.

### Mechanism and Context
- **How TRQs Work**: The U.S. Trade Representative (USTR) and USDA allocate quotas, often through trade agreements (e.g., WTO, USMCA). Within-quota imports get preferential rates (often 0% from FTA partners like Canada), while over-quota imports face the ‚Äúmost-favored-nation‚Äù (MFN) rate or higher specific duties from the Harmonized Tariff Schedule (HTS).
- **Administration**: The U.S. Customs Service tracks imports, applying over-quota rates when thresholds are crossed. 
- **Trade Agreements**: USMCA eliminates over-quota tariffs for Canada and Mexico on most goods (e.g., dairy up to 50,000 tons for Canada), but non-FTA countries (e.g., Brazil, India) face them.

In summary, U.S. over-quota tariffs range from 10% (dairy) to 350% (tobacco), with peanuts (163.8%) and sugar (150-200%) among the highest
